Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5SNK-5331-JDG9-Y471-00000-00Complacency about artificial intelligence is topic of Poynter lecture2018-10-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:35:47ZLexisNexisComplacency about artificial intelligence is topic of Poynter lecture

New Haven: Yale University has issued the following press release:

Researcher Julia Powles will explore mounting fears about artificial intelligence in her talk “Big Tech and AI Complacency,” which she will deliver on Monday, Oct. 29, as a Poynter Fellow. The talk will take place at noon in Rm.

127 of Yale Law School, 127 Wall St. The event is free and open to the public. Powles is a research fellow at Cornell Tech and at New York University’s Information Law Institute. She primarily focuses on the politics and law of technology, bringing expertise in privacy, intellectual property, internet regulation, and data protection. Previously, Powles was a postdoctoral fellow in computer science and law at the University of Cambridge, a speechwriter for the director general of the World Intellectual Property Organization, and a contributing editor at the Guardian newspaper. Writing for the Guardian, she covered the topics of technology and privacy. Powles has worked as a lawyer, scientific researcher and clerk for the Federal Court of Australia and Administrative Appeal Tribunal. She holds a Ph.D in law from the University of Cambridge, a master’s in law from the University of Oxford, and an undergraduate honors degree in science from the Australian National University and law from the University of Western Australia. At the University of Cambridge, her projects focused on data sharing, artificial intelligence and healthcare, privacy and security in connected environments, ethics in big data research, automated decision-making, and patenting in the life sciences. The Poynter Fellowship in Journalism was established by Nelson Poynter, who received his master’s degree in 1927 from Yale. The fellowship brings to campus distinguished reporters, editors and others who have made important contributions to the media. Among recent Poynter fellows are Xyza Cruz Bacani, Maria Konnikova, and Claudia Rankine.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5STK-8F81-F03R-N0S6-00000-00Complaints Made To Regulators Since GDPR Went Into Effect2018-07-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:35:47ZLexisNexisComplaints Made To Regulators Since GDPR Went Into EffectKing Spalding

Jul 16, 2018( JD Supra: http://www.jdsupra.com Delivered by Newstex) It is now over six weeks since theEU General Data Protection Regulation went into effect on May 25, 2018. We are aware of various reports to confirm that GDPR has already had the wide-ranging global impact it was expected to have. Multiple U.S.-based news sites, such as the Los Angeles Times, continue to restrict access to EU users with the message that its 'website is currently unavailable in most European countries.'

Furthermore, we are aware of the high profile complaints already filed by a French NGO[1] regarding the practices of big tech companies. But what about complaints? Are consumers rushing to raise data protection complaints with their local data protection authorities ('DPAs')? Data obtained by IAPP[2] (the International Association of Privacy Professionals) suggests a variance of results, with some DPAs failing to respond. For those who did, the reports varied significantly with Sweden reporting as few as 2 complaints in the month since GDPR came into effect, and the highest numbers of complaints being reported in the Republic of Ireland, France, and the Czech Republic. The UK and Germany did not provide responses to the information request. The next question to consider is when the first enforcement actions under GDPR are to be expected. As we know, the DPAs have a statutory duty to investigate complaints made under the previous EU legislation. Many DPAs are therefore necessarily working through the back log of existing complaints. Whilst there are no official reports on when the first enforcement action under GDPR will take place, it is estimated, based on previous data on the DPAs response time to incidents, that it will take until the end of this year or the beginning of 2019 before GDPR enforcement action is being reported. We will continue to keep you informed about developments in the law, practice and actions under GDPR. [ 1]: https://www.kslaw.com/news-and-insights/data-privacy-security-practice-report-june-4-2018 [ 2]:   https://iapp.org/news/a/cataloguing-gdpr-complaints-since-may-25/

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VT7-R5N1-JCMN-Y1Y2-00000-00Complete Overreaction: Professor Calls For Shutting Down Facebook Live, Post-Christchurch2019-04-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:35:47ZLexisNexisComplete Overreaction: Professor Calls For Shutting Down Facebook Live, Post-ChristchurchMike Masnick

Apr 03, 2019( Techdirt: http://www.techdirt.com Delivered by Newstex) It is generally a bad idea to make any massive change in the wake of a tragedy. It is certainly reasonable to explore and discuss some of these ideas, but the temptation to overreact to an emotional sample size of one is often too great, leading to very silly outcomes. Take, for example, a suggestion by professor Jennifer Grygiel, in the wake of the awful attack in Christchurch, New Zealand a few weeks back. As with other "blame the tech" attempts, her focus is less on the speed with which the platforms removed content, but more with the fact that live-streaming is even available at all.

Her proposal? No more live-streaming at all[1]. Grygiel at first repeats an earlier argument she made that all live-streaming must be put on "time delay" for censors to review. She notes that she first pushed this idea a few years ago, in the wake of another "streamed live" attack.In the wake of Godwin's murder, I recommended that Facebook Live broadcasts be time-delayed[2], at least for Facebook users who had told the company they were under 18. That way, adult users would have an opportunity to flag inappropriate content before children were exposed to it. Facebook Live has broadcast killings[3], as well as other serious crimes such as sexual assault, torture, and child abuse[4]. Though the company has hired more than 3,000 additional human content moderators[5], Facebook has not gotten any better at keeping horrifying violence from streaming live without any filter or warning for users.But, wait, you say: how does this work? Apparently the idea is that adults are allowed but kids are magically put on time delay. Well, now we've massively scaled back the proposal such that a very small percentage of the userbase is effected (which, is certainly better, but...). Of course, there's no indication that the problem of streaming these videos live was that any kids watched them. Indeed, I've heard no such reports. So this "time delay" plan wouldn't have stopped nearly all of the people who did see the video. Second, this whole plan assumes that (a) the only reason these attacks occurred was because of the ability to live-stream, and (b) that there aren't other live-streaming options out there (there are many). It also ignores that even if "adults" were able to view the content first, there's no indication that they would report it. Indeed, Facebook noted that less than 200 people viewed the initial live-stream, and no one reported it. So, that would mean that this video still would have gone out to anyone after the "time delay" even if Grygiel's plan was in place.Facebook relies on users as moderators, and most livestreams don't have as large an audience as TV, so its delay would need to be longer — perhaps a few minutes. Only then would enough adult users have screened it and had the opportunity to report its content. Major users, including publishers and corporations, could be permitted to livestream directly after completing a training course. Facebook could even let people request a company moderator[6] for upcoming livestreams.Except, again, no one reported the original video, so nothing would have changed with this plan. And lots of recent mass killings and attacks weren't live-streamed by the killers (in fact, most are not). This plan seems to be taking a side issue (live-streaming) with the real issue: a very terrible, sick person decided to kill a huge crowd of people for terrible reasons. For what it's worth, Grygiel also seems somewhat confused about the legal aspects of all of this:Facebook has not yet taken this relatively simple step, and the reason is clear. Time delays took hold in TV only because broadcasting regulators penalized broadcasters[7] for airing inappropriate content during live shows. There is effectively no regulation[8] for social media companies; they change only in pursuit of profits[9] or to minimize public outcry[10].First off, it's not a "relatively simple step." It's actually asking for something that is incredibly complex and would likely create lots of problems, with little obvious benefit. Second, the reason that broadcasters can be penalized is because they are using the public airwaves, which they got in exchange for certain conditions placed on them regarding obscenity. The internet is not like that, and part of the reason that there's "effectively no regulation" on the internet is because the First Amendment bars it. While I'm sure that "pursuit of profit" is clearly a driving force for all of these internet platforms, to argue that that is their only driving force, and that they don't care about the wider impact is a fun narrative totally devoid of actual understanding of those who are operating these platforms. Either way, without recognizing any of this, Grygiel then says that after Christchurch she doesn't even think the time delay idea is enough, and that live-streaming should be banned -- unless all content is "professionally moderated" a la television.That's why I'm no longer recommending just a livestream delay for adolescent users — it was an appeal to protect children when more major platform changes are unlikely. But all people deserve better and safe social media. I'm now calling on Mark Zuckerberg to shut down Facebook Live in the interest of public health and safety. In my view, that feature should be restored only if the company can prove to the public — and to regulators — that its design is safer. Handling livestreaming safely includes having more than enough professional content moderators to handle the workload. Those workers also must have appropriate access to mental health support[11] and safe working environments, so that even Facebook employees and contractors are not unduly scarred by brutal violence posted online.This is a massive overreaction to a few crazy people using one particular tool. Yes, we agree that most people should not watch these videos, but using the very, very, very edge case to argue that live-streaming shouldn't exist makes no sense at all. Again, most mass shootings aren't live-streamed. And the ones that are still aren't viewed by that many people. And, as a society, we're (thankfully) learning not to share the video around as much (yes, there are trolls and assholes who are posting it, but unless you were really looking for the video, you weren't going to accidentally stumble over it). And most kids I know aren't likely to go searching for such a thing. What happened in New Zealand was truly awful. But overreacting like this does no one any good at all.Permalink[12] | Comments[13] | Email This Story[14] [ 1]: http://www.niemanlab.org/2019/03/after-new-zealand-is-it-time-for-facebook-live-to-be-shut-down [ 2]:   https://www.cbsnews.com/news/cleveland-murder-raises-questions-about-violent-videos-on-facebook/ [ 3]:   https://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/news/2017/04/25/father-livestreams-killing-infant-daughter-facebook-live/100884906/ [ 4]:   https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/alexkantrowitz/heres-how-bad-facebook-lives-violence-problem-is [ 5]:   https://money.cnn.com/2017/05/03/technology/facebook-content-moderators/index.html [ 6]:   https://slate.com/technology/2017/08/a-modest-proposal-to-moderate-trumps-tweets.html [ 7]:   http://us.cnn.com/2004/SHOWBIZ/TV/02/03/grammys.tape.delay/index.html [ 8]:   https://doi.org/10.1016/j.telpol.2018.12.003 [ 9]:   https://theconversation.com/big-tech-isnt-one-big-monopoly-its-5-companies-all-in-different-businesses-92791 [ 10]:   https://www.nytimes.com/2018/11/15/technology/facebook-definers-soros.html [ 11]:   https://www.theverge.com/2019/2/25/18229714/cognizant-facebook-content-moderator-interviews-trauma-working-conditions-arizona [ 12]:   https://www.techdirt.com/articles/20190328/18190141893/complete-overreaction-professor-calls-shutting-down-facebook-live-post-christchurch.shtml [ 13]:   https://www.techdirt.com/articles/20190328/18190141893/complete-overreaction-professor-calls-shutting-down-facebook-live-post-christchurch.shtml#comments [ 14]:   https://www.techdirt.com/articles/20190328/18190141893/complete-overreaction-professor-calls-shutting-down-facebook-live-post-christchurch.shtml?op=sharethis

urn:contentItem:60HR-HYH1-JCBW-N0Y1-00000-00'Complete rethink' needed to keep tech giants in check2020-08-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:35:47ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2'Complete rethink' needed to keep tech giants in checkDaily Telegraph Reporter

TECH giants will dominate people's lives for decades without a "complete rethink" on how digital data are collected, researchers claim.

A study by the Institute for Public Policy Research claims six firms - Facebook, Google parent company Alphabet, Apple, Microsoft, Netflix and Amazon - are gaining ever-increasing control over valuable information.

The report says a new UK digital data regulator should be created to drive open access and common ownership of data.

It also urges better protection for particularly sensitive data, such as those derived from the NHS.

The report highlights that the combined value of the big six has risen by more than $1.9trillion (£1.4trillion) since the start of the coronavirus pandemic, and argues that the outbreak has caused society to become even more dependent on data as a result of remote working and increased medical surveillance to help fight the virus.

The report also suggests that this value increase among the biggest firms reflects the expectation that they stand to gain disproportionately from the shift to more data dependence.

James Meadway, associate fellow at the institute and author of the report, said: "Covid-19 risks further increasing the economic and social dominance of big tech, with stock market valuations skyrocketing as society becomes more dependent on data through homeworking and increased medical surveillance.

"This Covid effect means their power to affect and influence our daily lives is becoming increasingly removed from public control."

The report calls for local authorities to push for data collected in their area to be made open and accessible in an anonymised form to help with other projects.

urn:contentItem:5XFH-MVD1-JCMN-Y19F-00000-00Compliance in Era of EU's New Anti-Competition Climate2019-11-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:35:47ZLexisNexisCompliance in Era of EU's New Anti-Competition ClimateNAVEX Global

Nov 06, 2019( JD Supra: http://www.jdsupra.com Delivered by Newstex) [author: Matt Kelly]Later this fall something unprecedented will happen at the European Union: Margrethe Vestager will begin a second five-year term[1] as the EU competition commissioner. Corporate compliance officers and risk managers should brace themselves for what comes along with that: a more emboldened Vestager, trying to develop new approaches to antitrust enforcement and new remedies for companies whose business conduct goes too far. Earlier this fall, however, Vestager told EU lawmakers that monetary penalties are not 'doing the trick' — and in her second term, she'll also have expanded authority to shape Europe's digital economy policies.

Vestager's first term was marked by huge regulatory fines, many of them against large U.S. technology companies. Earlier this fall, however, Vestager told EU lawmakers that monetary penalties are not 'doing the trick' — and in her second term, she'll also have expanded authority to shape Europe's digital economy policies. All of that might prompt compliance officers to reach for some antacids. We should also take this moment to ponder what expanded antitrust enforcement might look like in Europe, and how companies should anticipate what that landscape means for compliance. Related CoursesFirst, the Big Concepts Antitrust concerns fall into two broad categories. First, a company might become so powerful that it harms consumers, typically by forcing them to pay higher prices. A company can also become so powerful that it stifles competition from other firms, reducing the choices that consumers have in the market.Of those two categories, Big Tech clearly falls into the latter camp. It's difficult to argue that those companies harm consumers through higher prices, since most social media and Internet businesses give away their product for free. Instead, critics say, Big Tech harms other companies' ability to offer alternate products. Vestager is one of those critics, and that's an important clue about where her enforcement priorities lie. If fostering more market competition is her goal, then Vestager will tilt more toward structural remedies that prevent anti-competitive behavior, rather than mere monetary fines after the behavior has happened. Implementing structural remedies that change how a company conducts business — hmmm. That sounds like something compliance officers might handle. So what would those remedies look like, and what capabilities would compliance programs need to have to implement them? Interim Measures, Market Reorganizations ...reFirst, Vestager (or any other EU competition commissioner) could order 'interim measures.' That essentially directs a company to pause whatever alleged anti-competitive practice the Competition Commission is investigating. Interim measures are stronger than a request, but less than a consent decree that you might typically see at the end of an investigation. The Competition Commission has had the power to issue interim measures for many years — but never actually used them until several weeks ago, when Vestager imposed interim measures[2] on a U.S. microchip maker. The measures will remain in place for three years or until Vestager finishes her antitrust investigation, whichever comes first. More ambitiously, Vestager is also mulling changes to the burden of proof[3] that tech companies would need to show to avoid anti-competition punishments; and may even seek the power to 'reorganize' markets[4] before Big Tech swoops in with behavior EU officials view as harmful. In the extreme, Vestager does have the power to order the breakup of a large, powerful company. Politically, however, that seems like a can of worms nobody wants to open.Much more likely is that Vestager will keep trying to cultivate measures that can change how a business operates: closer review of proposed M...eals, divestiture of some operating units to win regulatory approval, consent decrees to guide certain behaviors, and the like. Plus her office still has that power to levy billion-euro fines, too. 4 Implications for the Compliance Function Whatever brave new world Vestager brings about, for corporations (especially tech firms), the risks of regulatory enforcement[5] are going up. That has several implications for corporate compliance, legal, and risk functions. More attention to anti-competitive issues in pre-acquisition due diligence. Compliance officers already should play a role in pre-acquisition due diligence to find potential trouble in bribery, ethical sourcing, money laundering, or related risks. Now companies will need to contemplate anti-competition issues as well. More attention to new products or services. One of Vestager's beefs with Big Tech is that large firms start with one flagship product (online communities, search engines, e-commerce), and then start offering other services (messaging, mapping, travel booking) that compete with smaller companies. Companies will need to be better at analyzing potential regulatory consequences of those business development plans. A better ability to replicate or split off compliance programs. In more difficult cases, a company might need to expand compliance programs rapidly across newly acquired businesses, or to split off compliance programs with an operating unit that's being divested. The skill to do those tasks will become more important. A better ability to freeze business practices under regulatory review. Remember those interim measures Vestager has shown a willingness to use. When a regulator tells a company, 'Stop doing this,' that requires policies, controls, and monitoring to confirm that you've stopped. We don't know when Vestager will get expanded enforcement powers, or just what those powers might be. Still, those powers are likely to arrive eventually. Even if Vestager can't use them herself before her second term expires, she could set the precedent for much more complex, nuanced EU antitrust enforcement for years to come. Compliance officers should plan accordingly.View original article at Ethics ...mpliance MattersTM [6] [ 1]: https://www.wsj.com/articles/no-relief-for-big-tech-under-new-eu-leadership-11567428651?mod=article_inline [ 2]:   https://www.ft.com/content/652d2d60-efaa-11e9-ad1e-4367d8281195 [ 3]:   https://www.ft.com/content/24635a5c-fa4f-11e9-a354-36acbbb0d9b6 [ 4]:   https://www.wsj.com/articles/she-fined-tech-giants-billions-of-dollars-now-she-wants-sharper-tools-11571131520 [ 5]:   https://www.navexglobal.com/en-us/solutions/regulations?source=JD%20Supra [ 6]:   https://www.navexglobal.com/blog/article/compliance-in-era-of-eus-new-anti-competition-climate/

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5X05-7XC1-DY6Y-M3NP-00000-00Composer Kamala Sankaram on Expanding Opera's Audience With a Techno-Infused New Work2019-09-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:35:47ZLexisNexisComposer Kamala Sankaram on Expanding Opera's Audience With a Techno-Infused New WorkBilly McEntee

Step aside, "Netflix and chill"-opera is experiencing a vital revolution and composer Kamala Sankaram may be its savior. With her new opera Looking at You, Sankaram is crafting a piece that speaks directly to our digital age but with a performance that has to be experienced IRL. More than the traditional art form one associates with older patrons and even older scores, classical music and opera has long been reconsidered in New York thanks to organizations like   Heartbeat Opera, Groupmuse, and now the arts center   HERE and   Opera on Tap, two groups that are presenting the world premiere of Sankaram's stirring and contemporary new work from September 6 through 21. With her librettist Rob Campbell, Sankaram explores-via a techno-noir score-the way capitalism, the erosion of online privacy, and the quest for individualization collide in our post-Y2K society. We spoke to Sankaram about the technologically complex new piece and what it's going to take to expand the audience for opera.

SEE ALSO: The Dramaturge of a Bold New 1920s-Set 'Magic Flute' Explains the Enduring Modernity of Mozart

Observer: Opera is often misunderstood as stuffy, but there's also been such fresh and vital opera in New York of late. What attracts you to this art form? Kamala Sankaram: I think that there is so much baggage attached to the word "opera" because of how we think we're supposed to experience it: decked out in pearls and totally quiet. I had a conversation with a cab driver recently that drove this home for me. He asked what I was doing in town, and I told him I had written an opera. He immediately said, "I don't like opera." And I said, "Oh? Why? Which opera don't you like?" And he said, "I haven't actually seen any." So I asked him how he knew he didn't like it, and he said he didn't like it because of how it sounded on TV commercials. So the cultural depiction of opera represents it as something kind of fuddy duddy and boring, and that becomes what people think of opera, even if they've never actually heard one.

I didn't actually grow up with opera either. While my mom loves classical music, her tastes run mostly to instrumental and symphonic music. And my dad (who is from Andhra Pradesh, India) pretty much only listens to Indian classical music and Bollywood. So, that's what was played in my house. I sang in the choir and joined the theater class. All this is to say that I think that many different kinds of people from many different backgrounds would enjoy opera if they could get over the first step of coming to the performance.

This preview you've released of the work is so cool-very compelling how colloquial the lyrics are, and how familiar the techno-infused composition is. These are not the elements that often come to mind when we think of (traditional) opera. Do you feel in a way you are subverting or expanding the form?I guess it depends on what you believe the form is. I believe that opera is a music-forward form of storytelling. By that definition, this is an expansion. The composers of the canon were not shy about using all of the musical tools at their disposal to create their work, and I don't think that contemporary composers should be either. That being said, there are people who will not consider this an opera (and they have come to previous workshops of the show!) because it isn't in a big house and doesn't use a big orchestra. However, I think that for the art form to stay alive and healthy, it must embrace manifestations that appeal to a contemporary audience that doesn't know the canon at all. It must fit in spaces where the tickets are affordable, and where people can come without feeling intimidated.

What inspired you to tackle the intersection of capitalism and the erosion of privacy in our increasingly digital world?My earliest experience of the internet was on Bulletin Board Systems (BBS). There was something so open about it: you didn't know who you might meet, or where they might be. Because of that, everyone thought the internet would let the whole world become more open. Instead, what has happened is that new gatekeepers have emerged who are not only preventing that openness, but are finding ways to monetize the most intimate details of our lives.

The most chilling aspect of all of this is that we don't know what the future uses for this data will be. We also don't know how decisions about how the data should be evaluated and used data are being made, since much of this decision-making is being left to algorithms trained through machine learning. In a nutshell, to train up an algorithm, you feed it data in order to get a desired output. If the output isn't what you want, you change the parameters of the algorithm until it does give you the answer you want. For example, you could feed an algorithm a set of pictures until it can accurately label a face as a face. Then you send that algorithm out into the world to do facial recognition on new photographs.

But you don't really know what the rules are that it's using to make its decisions because you can't see inside what's called the black box­ - the pattern in the data that the algorithm is using for decision-making. The thing that we don't talk about enough is that the way the algorithm functions is totally dependent on the kinds of data it was trained on. Because of this, biases are coded in. Facial recognition algorithms have trouble with Black faces. Google   shows women ads for lower paying jobs than men. We're in a pivotal moment where we can decide as a society that we care about these issues, and we can insist that there is some kind of regulation and oversight for the big tech companies that are creating these algorithms and outsourcing decision-making to them. But that will only happen if people become aware of how pervasive and potentially harmful the problem is.

You're partnering with a number of technology groups-Bandcamp, BluPanda, video designers-to create a certain ambiance for the show. Can you discuss what audiences may be walking into?I can't say too much, but I can give you the broad strokes: You have been invited to the welcome party for Dorothy, the new chief engineer at Rix, a small company in Silicon Hills. On your table is a tablet computer that will help you get a free drink. Soon the tablets in the space become the chorus for the show. And as the narrative progresses, the tablets transform into something more sinister... the algorithm.

Again, without giving too much away, let's just say this is a fully immersive experience, meaning you can agree to be part of the show without actually having to leave your seat or even interact with the singers. Kristin's staging takes place all around the space, and I should also mention the tremendous video design by David Bengali, which includes unique content on each tablet, as well as on screens throughout the theater.

This might be a little out of left field, but something your opera reminded me of is the backlash Joaquin Castro experienced, in certain circles, for sharing public information about top Trump donors. The internet indeed wields a lot of potential-do you feel like your opera has become increasingly topical in a way?I think it becomes more topical every day. We are only now beginning to recognize the immense impact that internet companies have on not only our democracy, but our economy and almost every aspect of modern life. But we do need to make a distinction between the internet itself and the gatekeepers who have monetized it. On its own, the internet is not a tool for good or bad. Rather, because we have let these large companies monopolize and curate our access, we have let what could have been a public good become another tool for corporate interests.

To your example, one unforeseen effect of the internet is callout culture. It's much easier now to point out things that we perceive as injustices or biases, especially among those who are politicians or celebrities. We don't address this specifically in the show, but it is definitely part of the question: what will your data be used for in the future? Right now, many politicians are being confronted with decades old tweets. Are there things that you've posted that you wouldn't want a potential boss or partner to see?

This interview has been lightly edited and condensed for clarity.

Looking at You plays September 6 through 21 at HERE, 145 Sixth Avenue, New York, NY.

urn:contentItem:4DXP-GN90-TWD3-03B7-00000-00Computer Associates International Conference Call - Final2004-08-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:35:47ZLexisNexis081604ab.777Computer Associates International Conference Call - Final

OPERATOR: Good afternoon, my name is Amitras and I will be your conference facilitator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the CA eTrust Security solutions conference call. All lines have been placed on mute to prevent any background noise. After the speakers' remarks, there will be a question and answer period. If you would like to ask a question during this time, simply press star, then the number one on your telephone keypad. If you would like to withdraw your question, press star then the number two on your telephone keypad. Thank you. Miss Glass, you may begin your conference.

JEANNE GLASS, VP INVESTOR RELATIONS, COMPUTER ASSOCIATES INTERNATIONAL: Good afternoon, everyone and thank you for joining us. My name is Jeanne Glass, Vice President of Investor Relations at CA. With me today is Jeff Clarke, our COO and CFO and Russ Artzt, Executive Vice President of our eTrust Security business. The purpose of this afternoon's webcast is for Russ to provide investors and analysts with an overview of CA's eTrust strategy. Jeff Clarke will introduce the call, then Russ will deliver a short presentation and then he will host a Q&A. Before we begin, please note that this conference call is being broadcast over the phones and via a live webcast open to all interested parties. The content which is being preserved by means of a recording is the property of Computer Associates and is protected by U.S. and international copyright law and may not be reproduced, transcribed or produced in any way without the express written consent of Computer Associates. We consider your continued participation in this call to be a consent to our recording. I would also like to advise everyone that today's discussion may contain forward-looking statements under the federal securities laws. Consistent with all of our public statements there can be no assurances that future results will be achieved and actual results could differ materially from forecasts and estimates. Please refer to the Safe Harbor provisions contained in our earnings announcement and our SEC filings for further elaboration of the risks involved. You should also note that in accordance with SEC regulations, all guidance given regarding our business and future performance will be disseminated in a public forum such as this call, which is webcast and available to any interested party on our website. All future guidance and material information will be publicly disseminated in accordance with the requirements of Regulation FD. With that, please join me in welcoming our COO, Jeff Clarke. Jeff?

JEFF CLARKE, COO & CFO, COMPUTER ASSOCIATES INTERNATIONAL: Thanks, Jeanie. Good afternoon, everyone. In recent months I have talked about identifying a number of strategic opportunities that will strengthen the Company's leadership position in the rapidly expanding management software market. Those strategic opportunities include expanding our indirect and geographic footprint as well as making additional investments in high-growth areas such as securities and enterprise management. These four areas are critical in order for the Company to deliver sustainable future growth. We are expecting the successful execution in these areas to drive the Company toward high single-digit billings growth and, with proper expense controls, double digit cash flow growth in fiscal year 2006 and beyond. My expectation for cash flow in the current fiscal year remains unchanged. I still expect the Company to grow cash flows excluding the tax benefit or even when adjusted for tax payment and vendor financing. Today's webcast will focus on our eTrust Security business. Security is on top of the CIO's and CFO's minds, as many of you know. Growth in the securities sector is expected to outpace that of the overall software sector. Given the strength of our securities solutions, our customer base and our channel strategy, security will continue to be a growth driver for CA and a primary area of investment in our business. With that, I'd like to turn the call over to Russ, who will give you a complete overview of our security strategy. Russ?

RUSS ARTZT, EVP ETRUST SECURITY, COMPUTER ASSOCIATES INTERNATIONAL: Thanks, Jeff. Good afternoon, everyone. My name is Russ Artzt and I run the eTrust Security business unit. And today I'm going to be talking about our security management strategy. As many of you know, we are the management software experts. And we are rolling out a new strategy called our enterprise infrastructure management strategy, where all of our various solutions in the management arena, all integrate together into a very broad and very deep and powerful set of solutions. All of our solutions, whether they are in the storage management space or security management space under the business unit eTrust, operations management under Unicenter or lifecycle management under AllFusion are all integrated very tightly and as you can see in our enterprise infrastructure management vision, we include service management as an important component of our infrastructure management, including intelligence, and intelligence in all the various management areas. And as you can see in the middle, in management software all of our solutions are integrated, and we have taken all of our management solutions and will we use one MDB, one management database to store all the information related to assets in an IT enterprise, people, identities, and business policies. We've done this across all of our various business units. So that, for example, uh, between eTrust and Unicenter you have some very tight integration with some of the eTrust solutions and the Unicenter solutions by sharing information in a common database and I'll talk more about that as we move along. Enterprise infrastructure management is our strategy to, as you can see, simplify management, increase utilization, provide more effective real-time and on-demand processing, and aligns IT better with businesses. So let's talk a little bit about security management. Security management is integral to our enterprise infrastructure management strategy. We don't look at security as an island, it very much has to be integrated with the rest of our management software. Um, very quickly Gartner has predicted that by 2005, network and assistance management and security management will converge and will have to be managed together.

We have a philosophy of managing by assets and everything we do as you saw in the previous slide involves managing and securing those assets. And if you look at some of the IT processes that are critical today in terms of management, items like patch management, really require solutions that come from various management disciplines. If you look at patch management, and we'll get into that example in a minute, it really requires a complete solution and it's solutions that we provide, Computer Associates provides from our eTrust business unit as well as from our Unicenter business unit. And I will give you that example in just a minute. Other IT processes, like integrated operations management, as I said before, network, systems, performance, security management, all need to be tied together into an integrated operations management suite. If you look at help desks, most of the help desk calls today involve password resets which requires some of our eTrust solutions and certainly good governance and regulatory compliance require security solutions as well as other solutions, for example, from storage to enable a client or our customers to be regulatory compliant. You know, to give you some examples of what I mean by some of these integrated processes, if you look at integrated security business processes using enterprise information management and using EIM, typically a sample business process you go and in any environment you'll go and do an asset discovery, you'll then do a vulnerability assessment to assess based upon all the assets that were discovered in the environment to do a vulnerability analysis and basically to give a report as to how vulnerable an environment is and that can be done asset by asset. And then you put a remediation plan together. Well, typically today, what happens in an unintegrated environment is that clients are forced to buy point solutions, whether it's an Altiris or a Net IQ or a solution from Symantec, you know, these are solutions that aren't integrated and require a lot of corporate expertise that a lot of our clients don't have and require a lot of integration that our clients typically don't want to provide. As opposed to CA's philosophy and CA's philosophy, rather than have wasted dollars and not much intelligence across the various solutions, we believe in an integrated approach.

CA believes in modular integrated solutions and if you look at this particular business process, okay, this maps identically to the new vulnerability, managed vulnerability service that CA announced at CA World in May and is now going GA, going into production later this month, and it involves asset discovery, it involves vulnerability analysis, and putting your remediation plan that will involve patch management so that any of the patches that you desire being implemented will automatically be implemented to every desktop and every server in your environment. And even though these solutions go across different business units, go across Unicenter and eTrust, they are one seamless modular integrated solution. Now, if you look at our eTrust business unit, if you look at last quarter, Q1 fiscal '05, which ended in June, uh, eTrust Security was 17% of CA's overall bookings. As of June 30th, 2004, our trailing 12 months of growth was 43% over the same period of the year before. So as you can see, we have some very strong growth in our security business today. We have over 250 people now dedicated into the field. Um, besides having our security overlay team, um, who basically help provide direction to the field and help interface into my eTrust business unit, we have 250 people dedicated, you know, to field operations, both in sales and presales operations. We have made some very important investments in development. If you look at a lot of the products that I'll be presenting to you today on eTrust, many of them are brand-new products that didn't exist, like security command center and our eTrust vulnerability manager, are new products that didn't exist a year or two ago. We have a new security advisory team and this advisory team covers solutions from antivirus research to intrusion detection research to vulnerability research to spyware research. So we've made major investments in creating a cohesive security expert advisory team. We have made major investments in terms of building up our expertise in product marketing and product management. This is a very important area to CA, in the eTrust business unit our product managers drive all the requirements for what we need to develop.

In moving on if you look at our eTrust business unit we've divided it into three major areas, all, of course, related to security management and all relating to our enterprise infrastructure management strategy. One of the big areas and biggest areas of growth for us is in the identity and access management space. Most people in the industry call it the IAM space. It used to be the triple A space, so named by IDC. We call it IAM. It's really all about integrating our identity management solutions with our access management solutions and we'll talk more about that in a minute. A second big area for us is providing an integrated threat management suite. There are two major areas here in threat management for us. One is in secure content management and we'll go through what we mean by managing content, securing content. And vulnerability management. And the third big area is in the area of security information management. Solutions that will manage security holistically across the enterprise and will integrate well with many different third-party solutions. If you look at our addressable market today, it's very exciting. We're talking about billions of dollars even today in 2004, we're talking about $9 billion in 2008 growing to $15 billion marketplace. Okay. These are huge areas and the areas that we happen to address directly. Some of them are very, very large today, like secure content management, and only getting larger. Identity and access management is going to grow by 2006 to be a $6 billion business. And we're already one of the leaders in that space. Okay. And the security information management area is a new area. It's still relatively small but growing very, very rapidly and it's a sweet spot for CA in terms of our management prowess. So let's look at integrated threat management for a minute. A part of the threat management space is secure content management. And these are all the various components of secure content management that we feel are critical to having a successful, secure content management strategy.

All of these components we are either developing or through acquisition and we will have all of these components in place in the next six months. You'll be hearing very shortly about our new spyware solution, we are already a leader in antivirus and malicious code protection. We are -- we are working with various personal fire wall solutions. Today we OEM the Zone lab solution. Um, we have an anti-spam solution that we're developing very aggressively and you'll see some very attractive new solutions in that area in the next six months. Both, again, through internal development and acquisition. And the same goes for web filtering. We feel that all of these components are very important and very critical and must be integrated into one set of solutions so that the antivirus solution, the spyware solution, the spam solution, all work off of for example, common policies. All work off of a common GUI. All work off of a common management console. So that whether you're working on the desktop, on a server, on a PDA wireless device, on a gateway, okay, all of these solutions work together in an integrated fashion and in a seamless fashion so that security and secure content can be managed in an integrated fashion. Another big piece of what we do is in the area of -- in threat management is in vulnerability management. We at CA World announced a new managed vulnerability service and this involves CA coming in both with software technology, which we deliver as an appliance, but our co-managed service is all about providing experts, people as well as software. So in vulnerability management we are really offering two solutions. One we're going to be delivering as an appliance, we're announcing and then later this week and -- we are doing a big launch in the channel where we have hundreds of channel partners who are joining us to talk about our new vulnerability manager appliance. On that appliance is an integrated solution that does vulnerability analysis and automated patch management. It consists of software components that come from our eTrust business and our Unicenter business. For example, we use our Unicenter software delivery to automate and deliver the patches.

We're also offering a co-managed service and we'll be providing to our enterprise clients a service where we will help our clients and that is why we call it a co-managed service. We will work with our clients and help our clients to provide an expert security vulnerability service. Where we will go in and do analysis at the customer site, we will analyze from a vulnerability standpoint how vulnerable, how exposed are your systems. We will give you a complete report and analysis of where the potential exposures are. And we'll put a remediation plan together with -- with your people and show you -- give you a plan that will show you how to go about eliminating the exposures and vulnerabilities in your systems and then you'll be able to at the point that you're ready to, you'll be able to apply these patches in an automated way so that you'll be able to get rid of those exposures in your system that you're comfortable getting rid of. And keep in mind, we have a world-class vulnerability research team that validates every patch that we supply for any vulnerability out there and we -- and we support many, many different platforms. Our vulnera -- our security team will actually test and validate that the patch you're about to apply actually has been tested and will work and will not cause you other problems. So that's again part of our co-managed service. And if you look at our security advisory team, that's a 24 by 17, that's always on. If you go to CA.com you can click on security adviser and you'll very quickly get the security adviser web page that will tell you the latest in virus alerts, the latest in vulnerability alerts. Will give you the latest news regarding -- regarding security, threat notifications, um, threat notifications basically here you have a very valuable knowledge base. We actually get our research from over 400 different sources. We have patent-pending processes for furthering our research and testing and validating threats. We've taken our various research teams in antivirus and worm analysis and intrusion detection and vulnerability analysis and spyware and brought it all together into one security advisory team that is always on providing the latest research and we also provide a response team that will get you the latest information, you know, generally through an e-mail, to your client's site very, very quickly. Our response team prides itself in being the most efficient in the industry at getting you the latest information regarding threats in the environment.

In integrated threat management we have gone after some very important new areas. We've gotten very aggressive in our packaging and pricing of antivirus, which has helped us to gain market share and has helped us to be one of the real market leaders in antivirus. And you will see through acquisition and development in the next six months that we are absolutely going to be one of the top, top leaders in this industry. If you look at reach to market, we have partnerships with ISPs like Road Runner, like Yahoo, we have some very strategic partnerships with Microsoft, for example, and Cisco, we just joined the Cisco NAC program. We worked with Microsoft on -- we've been working with Microsoft very aggressively on their quarantine program so that all of our security products, not just antivirus but our -- but our vulnerability products and other security products are already integrated with the Microsoft quarantine program. Microsoft recommends us as a leading antivirus vendor, um, and uses some of our security information management products like our security command center to help them manage their own internal shows and -- and Tech Ed conferences. We also have a very important OEM program and system-builder program that we're developing. As I mentioned before, some of our software, like our vulnerability manager, we sell on an appliance and we are aggressively enhancing our OEM program with -- with our various eTrust solutions in the three major areas that I spoke about. We've had many new product introductions in hot areas, like vulnerability and patch management, a couple of years ago we didn't have a vulnerability and patch management solution. Today we have the most complete integrated vulnerability and patch management solution in the industry. Okay. Another hot area in secure content management, new product, okay. Security information management, we have our security command center, brand new product, that we announced 14 months ago and we have almost 300 clients. So these are all new areas and hot areas that we continue to develop in. And we will continue to grow both through internal development and acquisition. So let's look at one of our most aggressive areas of growth and that is in identity and access management. This is a critical area. And as we all know, you know, unless you understand your digital identities, you really can't be sure you're running a safe environment. More and more, our clients in CA we want to not only get control of who our internal population is, our employees and what they're allowed to access, but it's very important to be able to understand who you -- what your partner identities are.

Many of our clients want to deal with hundreds of thousands of partners, with millions of users, and in order to do that, you need a very highly scalable and very powerful identity and access management system. And that's what CA is all about with our IAM suite, identity and access management release 8 suite T's going GA at the end of October, this fall. All of our products are integrated, common web GUI, common directory, common provisioning enforcement and auditing capabilities providing as you can see here operational efficiency, because we automate all of the user provisioning, help you with regulatory compliance and certainly help you in terms of risk mitigation. And these are the three of the key areas in anybody's identity and access management set of products. And what we feel we're unique in is that we provide -- provide our solutions in an integrated seamless suite of solutions that all work well together from user provisioning to administration to enforcement, uh, to auditing, all of these solutions work hand in hand. And if you look at what we're doing in eTrust IAM, the market certainly is consolidating. There were a lot more competitors in the industry two years ago than there are today. We're seeing -- seeing lots of consolidation where, you know, just a key big vendors, the CAs of the world and IBMs are out there. We've made a lot of investment in research and development in our suite strategy. We're selling our products individually, we'll continue to sell each of our products individually, like our user provisioning product and access control product. But we're also creating suites and winning some very large suite deals where some of the largest companies in the world, some of the largest for example, financial institutions in the world and insurance companies in the world, banking companies are buying our solutions and we're in the process of implementing some very, very large implementations going on. We've taken a different strategy than some of our competitors. Like an IBM takes a strategy of, you know, we'll take care of things during the services part of things and deployment side of things, whereas we have a different philosophy. When we -- when you go and install our integrated set of products out of the box, they're all integrated and providing capabilities immediately as you install the products.

They're all designed to work together, to provide efficiency so that our clients aren't forced to have the expertise to integrate disparate products. Our philosophy is more we provide the integration in our factory and it enables our clients to get -- to become more efficient, to not have to spend millions of dollars integrating disparate products, spend, you know, lots of money trying to get individual products to work together from lots of different vendors, whereas our products are designed to provide out-of-the-box functionality and integration. Some of the clear differentiators for CA, we've always -- our goal, we're known as the Company, you know -- we're Swiss in that we support all the various platforms, we support over 100 platforms. And in this space of identity and access management, we've been the market leader now three years in a row in the areas of user provisioning, um, access control and auditing. And we've certainly are expanding our markets. More and more we're getting requests from some of our strategic clients to be able to embed our identity in access management solutions into processors that are sitting, for example, in vehicles, in cars, in trucks, in set-top boxes and more and more you will see our identity in access management solutions become much more pervasive and provide, really provide identity and access management inside, for example, a vehicle or a set-top box. So this is a very exciting new market that we -- that we have already gotten ourselves into in a very serious way. Now, if you look at security information management, this is an up and coming area. It's an area that involves managing security across the enterprise. We have invested in that space. We have a new product here that we've had for 14 months, our security command center. And really, our philosophy with our security command center is to be able to help our clients get control of their security management problems. Today, clients are getting millions -- literally millions of security-related events a day in various network devices, host processors, different systems, antivirus systems, access-control systems, intrusion-detection systems, firewall systems, and we have built a system with our security command center to be able to integrate, to be able to collect all the information from many, many different sources.

We have over 100 different product integration kits where we collect data using our robust auditing capabilities and we are able to aggregate the data, enable our clients to do analysis on that data, and to actually correlate the data to be able to make intelligent, automated decisions. So our security command center is a strategic product here in this area. And if you look at the security information management space, it's a new market. We've only been in it in 14 months. And we're one of the challenger leaders here with the best stability to execute. Certainly you see a lot of small companies. You know, in the visionary and upper right corner, which we're about to be in. We're kind of in the middle there. And we expect very soon to be the leader and to be the dominant leader in this space. Some big wins at Microsoft conferences like that big Tech Ed conference, security command center was securing and managing that conference. Um, the major summer sporting event going on right now in Athens is being secured by our eTrust Security command center and doing very well so far, holding up very, very well, our systems scale very well with lots of fall over capabilities, you know, if one processor goes down, it falls over into the next processor in a seamless fashion. Um, and we have integration with network management systems. For example, our security management systems security command center integrates well with our Unicenter network management system. And that's very important because a lot of our clients want to provide integrated security and network management. So we now have integration with our own Unicenter product and are working on integration into other popular network management systems, like HP OpenView. As you can see here, some of the business processes involved in security management can get very complex. Our security command center, as I stated before, can handle security events coming from many different sources, like intrusion detection systems, vulnerability systems, virus systems, firewall systems and our security command center is intelligent enough to interact with our vulnerability manager. And our vulnerability manager, um, also interacts with our asset management system. So, for example, if you are getting attacked by the famous Sequel Slammer virus, which only attacks systems that are running Sequel(ph) Server. Command center will right away ask our vulnerability manager, are there any Sequel server systems running at your site? And if there aren't, there's no problem and don't worry about it. And if there are, are they vulnerable?

Have patches been applied already? And if so, no problem. And if not, then the security staff and the network staff will be alerted immediately as to where the Sequel server machines are, will identify them immediately, and if necessary can immediately take them offline so that they're not susceptible to being attacked so that with an intelligent security management system and with intelligence in terms of what assets are involved with the type of attack that's being encountered, with vulnerability management systems that have a knowledge base of what patches are involved and what patches are needed to make the systems safe, we're able to provide a very intelligent enterprise-wide security management system. Lots of new opportunities in this area. You hear lots about co-managed services and managed services. We have chosen to get into the co-managed security service with our managed vulnerability service. We're looking at opportunities in consumer and SMB. These are new market places for CA. We've historically been very focused on the enterprise and the corporate accounts, large corporate accounts. Uh, we are -- we are -- we have put together some very important strategies in consumer and in SMB and we are actually developing and looking at potential acquisitions to help us in these critical new areas. I mentioned before we're getting involved in pervasive security and embedded security. For example, in many of your vehicles, if you look at some of your cars today, the very sophisticated, some of the new cars out there that are -- in some of the more sophisticated vehicles have basically have local area networks, networks of processors in the cars. And we're working very closely with some of these large companies to provide security embedded within the vehicle. And we'll talk more about it, you know, as some of our products come out. We're doing some very strategic partnerships with systems integrators. We're working closely with companies like Ernst & Young and Deloitte and Pricewaterhouse, EDS, CFC. We work closely with many different service providers, companies like Accenture.

So our whole partner ecosystem is expanding dramatically. I mentioned our partnership with Microsoft. We have a partnership with Cisco, we just entered the Cisco NAC program, Network Acceptability Program. We are working closely with other service providers as well. Like I mentioned EDS and CSC to provide complete solutions in this area of security. And we will be making announcements in the near future of other partnerships that we're engaging in, you know, in the managed security services arena. So, in summary, our eTrust business unit is all about managing security. We have focused in on three big areas, three growing areas that will represent a $15 billion marketplace in identity and access management across all the distributed platforms as well as the mainframe. In threat and vulnerability management, including what I call secure content management. And in the area of security information management. We're executing, it's a growth market, as everyone knows, this marketplace is growing. It is quite strategic. I've joined some of the most strategic security boards in the industry where I'm part of some boards that are all, you know, basically consist of CEOs of security companies, who are all working together to collaborate, to help provide good solid security standards and important security policies that will help the entire industry and will help our Federal Government in being proactive in terms of security management and in providing very solid security policies across industries. We're always looking at new opportunities, I spoke about security in vehicles. We're looking at other opportunities, you know, in the wireless space, in the web services space that we will be announcing, you know, as we move on during the fiscal year. eTrust is always on. We have a philosophy, uh, our management software is always there, is always ready. While it's invisible, it's inside, it's always acting, it's always responsive. And the same thing with our security products. eTrust inside our solutions are always on.

And are always doing things to protect the environment, to secure the environment. But we try to be as invisible as possible to the everyday operation. And certainly I think we know security is a key, key component of enterprise infrastructure management. Our overall strategy is that we provide the broadest and deepest set of integrated management solutions that are all tied together and certainly security is a vital part of that infrastructure management because infrastructure management always needs to be on, always needs to be managing and securing but should always be as invisible as possible. So that concludes my presentation this morning. I tried to give you an overview of what Computer Associates is doing. And as you can see, we are very, very active in the security space, focusing on security management. And what I'd like to do now is open it up for Q&A. And if you have any questions regarding my presentation or about CA as a Company, I'll be happy to respond to those questions. So thank you very much.

OPERATOR: At this time, I would like to remind everyone, in order to ask a question, please press star then the number one on your telephone keypad. We'll pause for just a moment to compile the Q&A roster. Your first question comes from Richard Sherman, Janney Montgomery Scott.

RICHARD SHERMAN, ANALYST, JANNEY MONTGOMERY SCOTT: Hey, good afternoon, thanks for taking the time to do this briefing with us. My question was about web services, you sort of hinted at some stuff coming in the web services area. Maybe you could flesh out a little bit more detail on that sort of what do you need to add to build out a solution or become more complete with your security solution in and around web services?

RUSS ARTZT: Sure. The question on web services, we're doing a lot of work at CA on web services. I've been collaborating both from the security business unit and with Mark Barrenechea on the Unicenter business unit. We are working on a combined management and security of web services. We'll have separate products, eTrust will have a web services security product, Unicenter will have a management product. In security, we're doing several things in web services. Number one, just like we can secure web resources, like secure web applications, we can secure URLs, we will -- we are building the ability to -- to secure web services as a real-time capability. We basically will, you know, we'll be able to see whenever a web service is invoked, whether it's a .net web service, or it's a J2 EE type web service. We will see it in flight, intercept it, and through our security policy engine, we'll figure out whether or not the user is allowed to get to that web services. We are using web services standards in that product. We are using -- in the Oasis Committee, which we're very involved, we use something called XACML, which is a policy language using XML to define security policy. Um, we're also using web services in our identity management products today so that partners can communicate with each other using techniques such as SAML and Liberty. We've already -- we offer SAML today and will be offering Liberty later this fall as a standard in terms of being able to do secure transactions from one company to another. So web services is a big part of our strategy. And again from a broad view, it's a matter of securing web services and manage them and you'll see some new eTrust products in that area later this year.

RICHARD SHERMAN: Russ, do you think the security aspects will be done at the directory or do you see it in a much more distributed end-point fashion?

RUSS ARTZT: We are using in web services we have something called UDDI, um, it's built into our directory. UDDI is kind of a medidata directory of all web services, so you store your web services under UDDI and you can store it in a Microsoft Windows active directory, you could store it in our directory, but we store all the web services in a UDDI directory.

RICHARD SHERMAN: Okay.

RUSS ARTZT: It's just a -- it's just another standard in web services today that we make use of.

RICHARD SHERMAN: Okay. All right. Thank you.

OPERATOR: Your next question comes from Sarah Friar with Goldman Sachs.

SARAH FRIAR, ANALYST, GOLDMAN SACHS: Russ, hi, you talked a lot about your work with Microsoft and so on. Obviously, one of the biggest risks to the industry or a lot of the risks that's talked about in the investment community is an entry by Microsoft with their own product. I wonder if you could talk a little bit about your thoughts there and maybe what you're strategizing to do should that happen.

RUSS ARTZT: Sure. Sarah, good question. We're working, as I said in my presentation, we're working closely with Microsoft, they are a very good partner. We have a great relationship with Microsoft. Um, in the event -- I mean, Microsoft -- you know, in the event that they do come out with their antivirus product, and, you know, I don't know how soon that will be, but in the event that they do, I believe that the antivirus market is -- is growing. First of all, I think they would come out with it in the consumer space, to start with.

SARAH FRIAR: Uh-huh.

RUSS ARTZT: My philosophy is and CA's philosophy is that we're building the antivirus solutions into a much broader set of solutions in what we call secure content management, which will include an integrated suite of products that will include antivirus, it will include -- include integrated spyware, uh, personal firewall, malicious code content, URL filtering, intelligent spam, so that in one set of solutions you'll have an integrated suite of what I call content management, secure content management solutions so that, you know, each of these solutions can share a common policy so that the client can set up one policy that relates to spam, content relates to spyware, relates to antivirus, and our one common user interface, one common management interface, we'll have a management console that will keep track of spyware and antivirus and spam on everybody's machine and at the gateway. You know, so there's a lot of antiviruses expanding into a much bigger marketplace, um, you hear a lot about spyware and how it's slowing down desktops and slowing down consumers and corporate desktops. We're investing a lot in spyware, you'll -- you'll hearing about what we're doing in spyware very shortly. So we're investing in this space and I think even if Microsoft comes in at the antivirus consumer level, um, we're planning on having a broader product line than that where antivirus will just be one component in a -- in a bigger picture. Vulnerability manager, for example, is another piece. Asset management's another piece, you know. So I think you need all of these solutions are related, uh, and we will be providing kind of more broader and more integrated sets of solutions.

SARAH FRIAR: Okay. That makes a lot of sense. Thanks a lot and thanks for doing the presentation today.

RUSS ARTZT: Sure.

OPERATOR: At this time, there are no further questions.

RUSS ARTZT: Okay. I want to thank everyone for joining us today. It was my pleasure. And I look forward to meeting with you in the near future. Have a great day.

OPERATOR: Thank you everyone for participating in today's teleconference. You may now all disconnect.
