Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5Y6P-7T31-JC11-11JP-00000-00Confronting a Data Privacy Crisis, Sen. Gillibrand Announces Landmark Legislation to Create a Data Protection Agency2020-02-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:35:47ZLexisNexisConfronting a Data Privacy Crisis, Sen. Gillibrand Announces Landmark Legislation to Create a Data Protection AgencyTargeted News ServiceWASHINGTON

Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand, D-New York, issued the following news release on Feb. 13:

* * *

- The Data Protection Act Would Create a Consumer Watchdog to Give Americans Control and Protection of Their Data, Promote a Competitive Digital Marketplace, and Prepare the U.S. for the Digital Age;

- U.S. Still One of the Only Democracies Without a Data Protection Agency

* * *

U.S. Senator Kirsten Gillibrand announced her landmark legislation, the Data Protection Act, which would create the Data Protection Agency (DPA), an independent federal agency that would protect Americans' data, safeguard their privacy, and ensure data practices are fair and transparent. The DPA will have the authority and resources to effectively enforce data protection rules--created either by itself or congress--and would be equipped with a broad range of enforcement tools, including civil penalties, injunctive relief, and equitable remedies. The DPA would promote data protection and privacy innovation across public and private sectors, developing and providing resources such as Privacy Enhancing Technologies (PETs) that minimize or even eliminate the collection of personal data. The U.S. is one of the only democracies, and the only member of the Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD), without a federal data protection agency.

"Technology is connecting us in new significant ways, and our society must be equipped for both the challenges and opportunities of a transition to the digital age. As the data privacy crisis looms larger over the everyday lives of Americans, the government has a responsibility to step forward and give Americans meaningful protection over their data and how it's being used," said Senator Gillibrand. "Data has been called 'the new oil.' Companies are rushing to explore and refine it, ignoring regulations, putting profits above responsibility, and treating consumers as little more than dollar signs. Like the oil boom, little thought is being given to the long-term consequences. The U.S. needs a new approach to privacy and data protection. We cannot allow our freedoms to be trampled over by private companies that value profits over people, and the Data Protection Agency would do that with expertise and resources to create and meaningfully enforce data protection rules and digital rights."

The agency will address a growing data privacy crisis in America. Massive amounts of personal information--public profiles, health data, photos, past purchases, locations, search histories, and much more--is being collected, processed, and in some cases, exploited by private companies and foreign adversaries. In some instances, the data was not given willingly, and in many others, consumers had little idea what they were signing up for. As a result, the data of everyday Americans is being parsed, split, and sold to the highest bidder, and there is little anyone--including the federal government--can do about it. Not only have these tech companies built major empires and made billions from selling Americans' data, but they spend millions of dollars per year opposing new regulations.

In recent years, major data breaches have occurred at banks, credit rating agencies and tech firms. In 2017, Equifax failed to safeguard the sensitive credit data of hundreds of millions of Americans, allowing a foreign government to steal and expose this information. In 2018, Facebook exposed the personal information of nearly 50 million users because it reportedly ignored warnings from its own employees about a dangerous loophole in its security. Additionally, the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) has failed to enforce its own orders and has failed to act on dozens of detailed consumer privacy complaints alleging unfair practices concerning data collection, marketing to children, cross-device tracking, consumer profiling, user tracking, discriminatory business practices, and data disclosure to third-parties.

The Data Protection Agency explained:

The DPA would be an executive agency. The director would be appointed by the president and confirmed by the Senate, serves a 5-year term, and must have knowledge in technology, protection of personal data, civil rights, law, and business. The agency may investigate, subpoena for testimony or documents, and issue civil investigative demands. It may prescribe rules and issue orders and guidance as is necessary to carry out federal privacy laws. The authority of state agencies and state attorneys general are preserved in the Act.

The DPA would have three core missions:

1. Give Americans control and protection over their own data by creating and enforcing data protection rules.

* The agency would enforce privacy statutes and rules around data protection, either as authorized by Congress or themselves. It would use a broad range of tools to do so, including civil penalties, injunctive relief, and equitable remedies.

* The agency would also take complaints, conduct investigations, and inform the public on data protection matters. So if it seems like a company like Tinder is doing bad things with your data, the Data Protection Agency would have the authority to launch an investigation and share findings.

2. Maintain the most innovative, successful tech sector in the world by ensuring fair competition within the digital marketplace.

* The agency would promote data protection and privacy innovation across sectors, developing and providing resources such as Privacy Enhancing Technologies (PETs) that minimize or even eliminate the collection of personal data.

* The agency would ensure equal access to privacy protection and protect against "pay-for-privacy" or "take-it-or-leave-it" provisions in service contracts--because privacy, including online privacy, is a right that should be enforced.

3. Prepare the American government for the digital age.

* The agency would advise Congress on emerging privacy and technology issues, like deepfakes and encryption. It would also represent the United States at international forums regarding data privacy and inform future treaty agreements regarding data.

The Data Protection Act of 2020 has been endorsed by leading technology, privacy, and civil rights organizations including:

* Electronic Privacy Information Center (EPIC)

"The US confronts a privacy crisis. Our personal data is under assault. Congress must establish a data protection agency. Senator Gillibrand has put forward a bold, ambitious proposal to safeguard the privacy of Americans."- Caitriona Fitzgerald, Policy Director, EPIC.

* Shoshana Zuboff, Charles Edward Wilson Professor of Business Administration, Emerita, Harvard Business School

"The Data Protection Act of 2020 by Senator Gillibrand offers a crucial bulwark against the pervasive assault on privacy that now disfigures every aspect of daily life. An overwhelming majority of Americans now think that the rampant commercial collection of personal data poses more risks than benefits, even as there is little choice but to depend upon privacy-destroying commercial systems for effective social participation. With this Bill, Senator Gillibrand joins a history-making new wave of legislative and regulatory efforts in the US and Europe that promise to assert democratic governance over commerce in the digital age. Senator Gillibrand's leadership is critical as we embark on the pivotal decade ahead." - Shoshana Zuboff, Charles Edward Wilson Professor of Business Administration, Emerita, Harvard Business School.

* Public Citizen

"It's no longer possible for individuals to protect themselves from intrusive online surveillance and manipulation. The FTC's response to even the most egregious privacy violations has been tepid, and so it is past time to invest in a new agency expert in how data is used and abused. As corporations gobble up more and more data as part of their day-to-day operations, we need a watchdog on the beat to stop them from breaking the law, and to provide meaningful consequences when they do. Along with new privacy laws that protect individual access to courts and don't scuttle the importance of the states, having a DPA is necessary to protect consumers in the digital age." - Robert Weissman, President, Public Citizen.

* Color of Change

"Current privacy laws give free rein to companies to exploit Black people's data, replicating and amplifying racial and economic injustices in the process. Senator Gillibrand's bill will advance civil rights protections for Black communities, and allow us to begin to take back our privacy in an era of unregulated big data. Federal oversight with the resources and authority to hold companies accountable to data protection obligations and tackle emerging privacy challenges is the key to ensuring our safety online." - Brandi Collins-Dexter, Senior Campaign Director, Color Of Change.

* Consumer Federation of America

"We support this legislation because protecting our privacy is a big job and we need an agency with the responsibility, resources and resolve to do it." - Susan Grant, Director of Consumer Protection and Privacy, Consumer Federation of America.

* U.S PIRG

"Senator Gillibrand's proposal for a strong Data Protection Agency recognizes that consumers need a tough, independent cop to protect their data and their privacy. The FTC is not that agency." - Ed Mierzwinski, Senior Director for Consumer Programs, U.S. PIRG.

* Center for Digital Democracy

"Americans are losing more of their privacy daily. It is wrong to assume, as industry likes us to believe, that individual consumers can manage their privacy in a world of non-stop surveillance. It is time we had 21st century safeguards in place. That is why we need a strong and independent data protection agency that will place the interests of consumers, and those most disadvantaged, ahead of the companies that regularly take all of our information and exploit us. The FTC has totally failed to protect the public for many years--regardless of which party has been in power. We applaud Senator Gillibrand's proposal, which if enacted, could help ensure that our digital rights are protected in the U.S." - Katharina Kopp, Ph.D., Deputy Director, Director of Policy, Center for Digital Democracy.

* Consumer Action

"As data violations occur at warp speed and with impunity, consumers need an agency that makes data protection its primary mission. Senator Gillibrand's plan to create a Data Protection Agency is the right step to ensure that companies use individuals' data fairly, responsibly and with accountability." - Linda Sherry, Director of National Priorities, Consumer Action.

* Campaign for a Commercial-Free Childhood

"The FTC has stood idly by while big tech companies have preyed upon children and families with an unfair business model based on illegal data collection and manipulative personalized marketing. Violations of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act are rampant as everyone, from major platforms to small developers, ignores the law. We applaud Senator Gillibrand for her legislation which would create a new COPPA cop to rein in the blatant and widespread misuse of kids' personal data." - Josh Golin, Executive Director, Campaign for a Commercial-Free Childhood.

* Parent Coalition for Student Privacy

"We endorse this important bill that takes the protection of our children's personal data out of the hands of the FTC, which has proven itself incapable of ensuring their privacy, and into the hands of a new federal agency which will be empowered to enforce the law, respond to parents' complaints when their children's privacy is put at risk, and analyze the potentially discriminatory impacts of current data practices." - Leonie Haimson, Co-chair, Parent Coalition for Student Privacy

* Professor Anita L. Allen, Henry R. Silverman Professor of Law and Professor of Philosophy, University of Pennsylvania Law School

"It is critical that Americans' personal data and communications finally be protected through the coordinated expertise of a dedicated federal agency." - Professor Anita L. Allen, Henry R. Silverman Professor of Law and Professor of Philosophy, University of Pennsylvania Law School

* Bruce Schneier, Fellow and Lecturer, Harvard Kennedy School

"Data centers in the U.S. are vulnerable to attack, and as a country we need to do a much better job with data security. That's why the U.S. needs a data protection agency." - Bruce Schneier, Fellow and Lecturer, Harvard Kennedy School.

* Professor Francesca Bignami, Leroy Sorenson Merrifield Research Professor of Law, The George Washington University Law School

"Just like 19th-century Americans got a federal regulatory agency to curb the power of the railway magnates, 21st-century Americans deserve one to tackle the problems of the tech industry. This Data Protection Agency is a vital step for protecting privacy and liberty in today's digital economy." - Professor Francesca Bignami, Leroy Sorenson Merrifield Research Professor of Law, The George Washington University Law School

The full text of the legislation may be found here. (https://www.gillibrand.senate.gov/imo/media/doc/2.11.2020_Data%20Protection%20Act.pdf)

Senator Gillibrand published a Medium post about her new legislation that can be read here. (https://medium.com/@gillibrandny/the-u-s-needs-a-data-protection-agency-98a054f7b6bf)

urn:contentItem:5Y4P-VWV1-JB4V-83J5-00000-00Confronting Bias: RNC Asks Supporters about Big Tech Censorship2020-02-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:35:47ZLexisNexisConfronting Bias: RNC Asks Supporters about Big Tech Censorship

Feb 04, 2020( Newsbusters.org: http://newsbusters.org/Delivered by Newstex) The GOP thinks that fighting Big Tech censorship might be a winning election issue. So much so, that the party is surveying voters about the issue as part of a nationwide grassroots effort.Former D.C. bureau chief for Investor's Business Daily and author Paul Sperry tweeted[1] 'BREAKING: New RNC questionnaire mailed to voters nationwide asks: 'Do you believe social media companies are suppressing conservative messages in order to influence public opinion and elections?''Earlier, Sperry had tweeted: 'BREAKING: In new mass mailer,RCN [sic] Chair Ronna McDaniel soliciting pro-Trump volunteers donors in 'the largest Congressional District Census our Party has ever taken for a presidential election' in order to build 'a nationwide, activist network second to none' for Nov GOTV effort.'He also observed[2] that 'BREAKING: RNC in new congressional district census recruiting pro-Trump volunteers/$ to 'invest heavily in opposition research ... grassroots organizing' ahead of Nov.

3 election to reelect Trump, take back House and stop Dems from enacting 'their Big Government Socialist agenda.''The Federalist's culture editor Emily Jashinsky responded via tweet[3] to the announcement by linking back to a blog she wrote 'Don't Minimize Conservative Concerns About Big Tech Censorship.'[4] This blog touched upon how Big Tech, as she described in her tweet, 'is now a kitchen table issue for Republicans.'She cited how a Media Research Center/McLaughlin Associates poll[5] which was 'conducted less than a year ago found that 65 percent of self-described conservatives 'believe social media companies like Facebook, Twitter, and YouTube are intentionally censoring conservatives and conservative ideas from their sites.''This same survey also found that '66 percent 'said they do not trust Facebook to treat all of its users equally regardless of their political beliefs.' But less than 7 percent said[6] they stopped using Facebook 'because of its censorship of conservatives.''The blog later quoted a survey[7] by Pew Research Center, which found that 'Republicans and Republican leaners are around twice as likely as Democrats to say [major technology companies] are less ethical than others (30% vs. 16%).' Jashinsky's blog remarked on how this survey 'also found 44 percent of Republicans and Republican leaners believe those companies should be regulated more than they are currently.' [ 1]: https://twitter.com/paulsperry_/status/1224770115104886785 [ 2]:   https://twitter.com/paulsperry_/status/1224769696924303361 [ 3]:   https://twitter.com/emilyjashinsky/status/1224790051835600898 [ 4]:   https://thefederalist.com/2019/06/10/dont-minimize-conservative-concerns-big-tech-censorship/ [ 5]:   https://www.axios.com/conservatives-social-media-censorship-poll-3a966ebb-6b44-458f-8941-40fc015a86a6.html [ 6]:   https://www.mrc.org/press-releases/mrc-poll-conservatives-leaving-facebook-over-censorship-bias [ 7]:   https://www.pewinternet.org/2018/06/28/public-attitudes-toward-technology-companies/

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WMT-6Y21-JB20-G3MF-00000-00Congress and White House Reach Deal on Spending, Debt Ceiling; WSJ: FTC Expected to Announce $5 Billion Settlement with Facebook This Week; WSJ: Boeing's 737 Max Grounding Spills Into Economy, Weighs on GDP; U.S. Denies Claim Iran Arrested 17 Citizens Accused Of Spying; South Korea Fires Warning Shots After Russian Plane Enters Airspace; RPT: Huawei Helped North Korea Build Wireless Network; Puerto Rico Protests2019-07-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:35:47ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA6:00 AM ESTChris Hogan, Mark AvalloneNEWSFinancial072301cb.231Congress and White House Reach Deal on Spending, Debt Ceiling; WSJ: FTC Expected to Announce $5 Billion Settlement with Facebook This Week; WSJ: Boeing's 737 Max Grounding Spills Into Economy, Weighs on GDP; U.S. Denies Claim Iran Arrested 17 Citizens Accused Of Spying; South Korea Fires Warning Shots After Russian Plane Enters Airspace; RPT: Huawei Helped North Korea Build Wireless Network; Puerto Rico ProtestsDagen McDowell, Cheryl Casone, Lauren Simonetti, Jackie DeAngelis, James Freeman, Jack Keane, Bryan Llenas, Deirdre Bolton

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Hey, Cheryl, what are you making a face at? It's delicious.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Cheez-It and wine?

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: No, she really likes it.

MCDOWELL: Cheddar cheese and red wine, Cheez-It, you know, it's not a big leap there. We will discuss --

CASONE: We will discuss. I'll see you in a minute.

MCDOWELL: -- as the morning moves on. Good morning, ladies, good morning everyone, I'm Dagen McDowell, in for Maria Bartiromo, it's Tuesday, July 23rd, your top stories at 6:00 a.m. Eastern.

Another big day of earnings, Dow components; Coca-Cola, Travelers, and United Technologies, all reporting this morning, along with Harley- Davidson, JetBlue, Lockheed Martin, we have the numbers, full analysis, as well as what to expect as earning season rolls on.

Futures are pointing to a higher open, this morning, 66-point gain on the Dow Futures, after a winning day on Wall Street yesterday, barely.

Making a deal, the White House and Congress, reaching an agreement on spending and raising the debt ceiling, we have the details. And the downside, Boeing's economic impact, the grounding of the 737 Max, taking a toll on the overall economy on airlines, suppliers, GDP, we break that down.

And countdown to Mueller, the former Special Counsel set to testify tomorrow with the Department of Justice saying that Bob Mueller must stick to what was in the public two volume Mueller report, we preview the big hearing and who might be disappointed when all is said and done.

MORNINGS WITH MARIA starts right now.

Joining the conversation this morning, FOX Business' Jackie DeAngelis, Wall Street Journal assistant editorial page editor, James Freeman and Ramsey Solutions financial expert, author of Everyday Millionaires, Chris Hogan, great to see one and all three.

JACKIE DEANGELIS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK FINANCIAL CORRESPONDENT: Good morning.

CHRIS HOGAN, FINANCIAL EXPERT, RAMSEY SOLUTIONS: Thank you.

JAMES FREEMAN, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Thanks.

MCDOWELL: Nice to see you, James, thanks for coming.

FREEMAN: Hey, good to be here.

MCDOWELL: Always. My mother told me, she was like, oh, I like him. He makes me laugh.

FREEMAN: Wow.

MCDOWELL: And I love listening to Chris Hogan and Jackie is so mart, so that's momma McDowell's summary of the panel.

HOGAN: Thank you.

DEANGELIS: Very sweet.

MCDOWELL: Futures are pointing higher this morning, as earning season really picks up steam. Dow components; United Technologies, Travelers, Coca-Cola and Visa, all will report their quarterly results today, along with Lockheed Martin and Snapchat.

Seventeen percent of the S&P 500 has reported second quarter results, 77 percent, beating their earnings per share estimates. Jackie, what are you watching this morning in terms of the big movers here?

DEANGELIS: Well, overall, we're seeing a good picture for earnings, and that's what investors really cared about, going into this earning season. You're seeing companies that are beating on EPS. We're not hearing the commentary, oh, we have problems in China. That's what everyone was looking for.

And you're also not seeing anybody really give any cuts on guidance going forward, as well. And this was really important to support the rally that we're seeing in the markets, so that investors know it's not just all Fed- driven.

Of course, this week, is going to be a really big week. We've got Coca- Cola this morning. We've got some of the big tech companies coming up, as well. But overall, in terms of kicking it off, it's gone off to a good start.

MCDOWELL: Right. Overall, so from the 17 percent of the S&P companies who have reported, the earnings are up more than 8 percent, so far, this year. The broad expectation, when all is said and done, is that earnings will fall this quarter, so we would technically be in an earnings recession. But again, they beat expectations, come in higher. We could have an up earning season, potentially.

DEANGELIS: Potentially.

MCDOWELL: Let's move on to making a deal, the White House and Congress coming to an agreement on government spending and raising the debt limit. The proposed budget includes about $2.7 trillion dollars over two years.

President Trump tweeting yesterday, I am pleased to announce that a deal has been struck with Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi, and House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy, on a two-year budget and debt ceiling, with no poison pills.

This was a real compromise in order to give another big victory to our great military and vets. James, your reaction, because again, it is $320 billion in spending over two years above the limit, set back in 2011. And that budget law, again, were staring down $1 trillion-dollar annual budget deficits and we get more spending.

FREEMAN: Yes, $22 trillion in federal debt. The bipartisan party continues. As the president mentioned there in the tweet, the Republicans wanted more defense spending. Democrats wanted more domestic discretionary spending, and so they compromise on more money for just about everything.

This is -- I think, really, the great failing of the Trump administration spending discipline, it just hasn't been there, not that it makes them unique among presidents, but you have to think at some point, there will -- there will be a reckoning, because as you mentioned already, projections are for another trillion-dollar deficit this year.

MCDOWELL: But the federal government can keep borrowing money at close to 2 percent a year, annually, over 10 years, that's where the yield on the 10-year treasury is. So, it's like, oh, we're not going to worry about it. Let's wait and make it somebody else's problem.

FREEMAN: Well this -- this is -- the story of the last 10 years -- the monetary policy Central Bankers are Fed driving rates so low. It's made it very easy for politicians to borrow. It's made it very easy to cut these kind of deals, and I think history would say, doesn't go on forever, but they're enjoying this spending right now in Washington.

MCDOWELL: Can I ask you this, would the economy be growing faster, do you think, if we didn't have headwind of this -- the annual budget deficits, where they are right now, and then the debt load, because again, in about five years, we're going to be paying more in interest on the national debt than we have pay in military and in defense spending?

FREEMAN: Yes. Well, I certainly think the key to growth right now, we see that -- recent results showing how the effective tax rate for corporations stock. It's now a competitive level for the rest of the world. I think that is the growth part of the Trump policy mix, the spending --

I think, he's thinking maybe this is a post re-election moment where he could have -- be able to cut some, kind of spending deal, maybe start to reform entitlements, but so far, no evidence that it's happening.

MCDOWELL: This has to make you crazy.

HOGAN: Oh, it drives me insane, Dagen, because we all know that this is not bipartisan, this is about budgeting, and you can't just keep overspending and overspending and expect someone to clean it up later. Someone's got to be adult enough to cut some things and start to put some limits in place. Otherwise, what we're passing on is -- debt handcuffs to people are younger generations.

MCDOWELL: Yes, but, you know what? That credit -- that credit card interest rate, I know it's -- the federal government doesn't have a credit card, but again, low, low, low interest rates. I can keep --

HOGAN: They've got things bigger than a credit card, right?

MCDOWELL: And you keep -- and you keep raising my --

HOGAN: That's right.

MCDOWELL: -- my credit limit.

HOGAN: That's right. And it looks like -- I agree with you, it's an attempt to appease, but ultimately, what it's going to be is a problem, that we all have to clean up a little bit later.

MCDOWELL: Yes. I wonder -- let me ask you this, is this -- does this mean you think that they could get infrastructure spending done? I don't think that --

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: Wait, what was that noise you just made?

FREEMAN: Well -- the

MCDOWELL: He just went --

FREEMAN: All right. I guess, in this spirit of bipartisanship, which I think we're seeing, is very overrated, right? There's a -- there's a benefit that the two parties not agreeing for another spending blowout. I would think, given the close -- how close we are to the election, maybe there wouldn't be time for that spending festival, but you never know.

I guess, hope springs eternal in Washington. Maybe they'll get another big deal.

MCDOWELL: Spending somebody else's money, spending borrowed money.

FREEMAN: Yes.

MCDOWELL: So, let's stick into the script, the Department of Justice telling former Special Counsel Robert Mueller that his testimony before Congress tomorrow, needs to stay within his public report. Maria Bartiromo spoke with Judiciary Committee ranking member, Doug Collins, on "SUNDAY MORNING FUTURES" about Mueller's upcoming remarks.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: What are you expecting from the Mueller testimony on Wednesday?

REP. DOUG COLLINS (R-GA): What we are expecting is another round of what we already know, telling some people, for it is like going back and finding a book on the shelf that looks new and then, all of a sudden, you begin to read it you find out wait, I've already read this before. And I think that's what the American people are going to find.

But, really, what's happening here, is that it's the Democrat's time to make the case, that they've not been wasting our time and millions of dollars and our committee hearings and clown and farce hearings going on over there, just harassing the president, going after things that we've already known, and just trying to make press release headlines instead of legislating and trying to govern our country.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: James, what are you watching for tomorrow, because I've made the jokes several times, of imitating Robert Mueller. Here's what Mueller is going to do, volume one, under one arm, volume two, and sit down and say, every question will, may I refer you to page 442.

FREEMAN: Yes.

MCDOWELL: That's how it's going to roll. But, what do you think? What are you expecting to see tomorrow?

FREEMAN: Yes, it could end up as a big dud, where he just refers to the document, but I think, for -- in terms of unanswered questions in there, I would -- I would love to hear his version, if he wants to tell it, of how the investigation -- the Russia collusion -- alleged collusion investigation really began in the government. When did it start? What was the real trigger?

And a little more background on the -- particular individuals, Mr. Smart Suit. I don't want to get too deep into the weeds here, but --

MCDOWELL: Oh, please, I love it. Go ahead.

FREEMAN: This is a -- this is a person who contacted George Papadopoulos. You remember when he came into the drama?

He was, at times, portrayed as the key to the whole thing, and basically, going back and saying, how did our federal government use its surveillance tools, which we had always been told were to go after terrorists and other bad guys against a rival political party? I think that's a big area in the report that is not completely addressed.

MCDOWELL: And one thing, but what Jerry Nadler is trying to do with this testimony, is shift the way people feel in this country, so he gets more people on-board with the idea of impeachment proceedings.

MCDOWELL: Welcome back. More problems for Boeing, the ongoing grounding of the 737 Max jet is actually hurting the entire U.S. economy. Economists say that the cut, in production, likely weighed on second quarter GDP, Gross Domestic Product.

And the impact could get worse as the situation wears on, joining us now, Potomac Wealth Advisors president and founder, Mark Avallone, good to see you, Mark. Talk about the impact of Boeing, but, at least, it would hopefully be transitory or certainly not permanent.

MARK AVALLONE, PRESIDENT AND FOUNDER, POTOMAC WEALTH ADVISORS: Well, I don't think it's going to be permanent, but nobody knows the exact deadline, so it's something in between. Now, the regulators and the inspectors are in there now, that really wasn't the case for Boeing.

They, kind of, had a cozy relationship, and now they are really being looked at closely and Airbus has made inroads, so this future becomes less certain, in terms of the economic impact. Look, there are less flights, that's less flight hours by pilots.

G.E. is taking a couple of $100-million hit from the engine sale reduction, so this has become -- becoming -- beginning to trickle across the economy. I don't see an immediate clear end. I think it's going to take time for Boeing to rebuild its reputation.

FREEMAN: Mark, James Freeman here at the Journal. Talking about their reputation, obviously, we saw with the -- order back log which they've had to delay here, the customers really have wanted this plane. They love the design. They love the concept of the product.

Do you think at the end of this, they still love it and it -- and it resumes its growth and becomes a mainstay of lots of fleets or has something changed here?

AVALLONE: Well, the airlines are in a tough spot because the bill time and the lead time for these airlines, is years. It's not like they can change their mind, walk down the street, and get another replacement plane. I mean, Boeing's had decades of great reputation and build out here.

So, I think they're going to hang in with them, look for an opportunity to say all is clear, get some really strong clearance from the FAA, and I think they'll hitch their wagon back to the Boeing Max. But it's not going to be in the next week or even months. I think it's more of a 2020 event, and that's why there's a little bit of uncertainty with the stock.

MCDOWELL: Busy week for economic data as well, GDP out on Friday, like we were talking about, Mark, but, in addition to Boeing's earnings, we've got Purchasing Managers' Indexes out tomorrow. European Central Bank meets Thursday. We've got home sales -- we've got new home sales tomorrow.

What are you expecting? Is this -- and how's that going to drive any potential decision-making by the Fed next week?

AVALLONE: Well, I think the Fed's decision, we've hinted, at least, is made. I don't know what's going to happen in the next week to change their mind. There clearly is a global economic slowdown. My concern is the ECB says they may lower rates, I'm not -- if lower rates were the answer, the European economic environment would be going gangbusters.

Lower rates there have actually worked negatively, their financial sector is in the doldrums, and I really wish they'd find another strategy other than lower rates. I think the Fed is going to follow almost because they have to, where our rates are significantly higher than other central banks. And the global economic slowdown may eventually trickle over here and impact our relatively strong economy.

DEANGELIS: Mark, it's Jackie DeAngelis, if we get a gangbuster GDP number for the second quarter like saw for the first quarter, do you expect the Fed to back off in any way, or do you think its hands are tied in the sense that it's told investors that it's going to give them the cut that they're looking for and that's part of the reason the markets rallied.

The Fed makes one cut and pauses from here. And let this relatively strong U.S. economy do the trick, in terms of continuing reasonable economic growth, and we stop looking day-to-day at what the Feds going to do.

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: They have tremendous problems economically, their country's in turmoil. They're having demonstrations all over Iran. Their inflation rates at 75 percent. MCDOWELL: Joining me now, retired four-star general, Fox News senior strategic analyst General Jack Keane. General, which way does it go, you think?

GEN. JACK KEANE (RET.), FOX NEWS SENIOR STRATEGIC ANALYST: Well, both countries want to avoid war. So, that doesn't mean, you could not be some kind of limited or measured conflict because we have a history of it.

And I think, right now, despite all the rhetoric, the balls a little bit in the United Kingdom's court. Because the Iranians have got their British tanker at Bandar Abbas Port, it's well secured there. I doubted there's any military operation in consideration by the Brits that will take the tanker back.

But what are they going to do? And literally, this week as you mentioned in the introduction, there'll be a new prime minister in England as the Conservative Party will elect the new head of the party who by definition will become the prime minister because Prime Minister May has stepped down.

First order of business will be what do we do about the Iranians? What do we do about our tanker? I hope the answer, Dagen, is that they move closer to the United States, join the maximum pressure campaign to put significant economic sanctions on Iran and come out of the nuclear deal.

That would be a huge plus and maybe too much to ask for. But at least, hopefully, they'll support the United States' position.

MCDOWELL: What kind of sanctions would we be talking about in terms of Great -- or the United Kingdom?

KEANE: Well, what I see happening there is most of the sanction on the oil exports with the exception of a few countries have really taken hold that's 80 plus percent. There may be some manufacture goods and some other things that the Brits are dealing with the Iranians on, and they can help us with those sanctions.

You know that the Iranians have busted the limits of Uranium restrictions imposed on as a part of the nuclear deal. And the reason for that is they want to get the United Kingdom, France, and Germany to provide them some economic assistance to minimize the impact of the U.S. sanctions.

To date, they have refused to accommodate the Iranians on that. But it's the French and Germans who truly want to do business with the Iranians. I think it's pretty shameful given the Iranians behavior.

But it's a business deal as far as they are concerned. If the Brits break away from the French and Germans, it's likely that French and the Germans will follow.

MCDOWELL: Would France and Germany be OK with a nuclear Iran? Again, that we are very far away, I would guess. Because I think it's you need 94 percent enrichment for weapon's grade uranium. But we're far away from weapons' grade material, but are France and Germany OK with a nuclear Iran not for power?

KEANE: No, they're not OK with a nuclear Iran nor is Russia or China OK with a nuclear Iran. And obviously, those two countries are adversaries and they work closely with Iran, and obviously, we do.

No, no one -- no one is in favor of a nuclear Iran. Why? Because then, the Arabs will go nuclear, and we will be in a nuclear arms race in the Middle East which is the most dangerous neighborhood in the world and could lead to possibly the first nuclear exchange. That's what makes this such a dangerous proposition, the Iranians pursuit of nuclear weapons.

MCDOWELL: I want to turn to South Korea. And I wasn't trying to -- General, I wasn't trying to be alarmist. But again, that's the ultimate question that all of these nations have to answer.

Our sanctions are working with Iran. Do you have runaway inflation in an economy that's cratering in the more, more of these actions by Iran, the more desperate they look? That should be a signal to our allies that they should join with us to take on this regime.

KEANE: There is no doubt about that. And the Iran is lashing out because they're back on their heels for the first time in 39 years. It's really quite stunning to see some of their erratic behavior because I believe it's also affecting their judgment.

We have -- we have a ways to go before the Iranians will come into and negotiate with the United States, principally or maybe some other allies because they've got more options in their playbook, and one of those options is clearly taking people's lives in the Middle East and possibly U.S. troops. That will, obviously, get a military response from us.

Hopefully, the Iranians do not go there, but it is in their playbook. And I do think they'll exhaust all of their options before they come to the negotiating table.

MCDOWELL: I want to move on and shift gears to South Korea. And South Korea -- the military there saying, its jets fired warning shots at a Russian plane that entered its air space. Russia denying the claim. Your reaction to that. Because again, hot spots around the globe and all of these -- all of these nations are connected to one another. Particularly with say, Russia, China, and Iran.

KEANE: Yes, most of these encouragers don't have military significance, but this one actually does. Because the Chinese and the Russians are conducting military exercises in the vicinity of South Korea. And they had -- they had an early warning radar aircraft up, which is command in control aircraft which we have in our arsenal as well, and that controls all of the fighters, and bombers, and the refuelers.

And that penetrated South Korean's air space as did Chinese fighters and Russian fighters, and that has never happened before. I think they were one of the reasons for that penetration of military significance is to test the South Korean's response.

Not just the physical response, but they're all -- they're watching the communications system, they're command and control, how quickly do they respond, what do they respond with, who was alerted? Et cetera.

So, this does have military significance. It's unusual for the Russians to have done this. South Koreas maintain this is the first time this has ever happened. I don't think it's necessarily an increase in tensions between South Korea and Russia or China.

I actually believe South Korea is kind of in China's orbit, to begin with, to be frank about it.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5X3J-GGX1-JBCN-43YW-00000-00Congress asks companies for big-tech complaints2019-09-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:35:47ZLexisNexisFRONT PAGEPg. 3Congress asks companies for big-tech complaintsJACK NICAS AND DAVID MCCABE New York Times Service

SAN FRANCISCO -- House lawmakers have asked more than 80 companies for information about how their businesses may have been harmed by Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google, according to four people familiar with the requests.

The House Judiciary Committee, which is investigating the influence of the tech giants, sent formal requests for information to the companies on Sept. 13.

They were asked about their own businesses and how the four tech companies may have engaged in anticompetitive behavior, according to the people who have seen the requests and spoke on the condition of anonymity because the lawmakers asked to keep the letters private.

The bipartisan requests from the committee indicated the increasing scope of the congressional investigation into Silicon Valley's power and offered more insight to the pressure Big Tech faces in the coming months. Similar inquiries are underway at the Justice Department, at the Federal Trade Commission and a bipartisan collection of attorneys general from dozens of states.

Lawmakers sent the requests on the same day they asked for scores of documents and personal emails from top executives at the four tech companies, according to the people. All of the companies have until mid-October to respond.

The additional letters to more than 80 companies show the breadth of the offensive forming against Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google. The recipients of the requests range from smaller firms in retail and advertising to large corporations in entertainment, software and social media, the people said.

A range of companies, including News Corp., Oracle, Spotify, TripAdvisor and Yelp, have complained about the behavior of the four big-tech companies and were likely to have received the requests. It was unclear how the queries to the more than 80 companies are split among the four tech giants.

One person familiar with the requests said lawmakers decided against publicizing the requests to protect the complaining companies from potential retribution from the four tech firms -- though those firms have said they do not retaliate against critics.

Companies have protested Silicon Valley's growing size and influence for years, but regulators and lawmakers in Washington have sharply increased their focus on Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google in recent months.

The House investigation is largely centered on the market power and alleged anticompetitive practices by the four companies. The committee is examining accusations that the big companies favor their own products over rivals, buy smaller firms to head off competition and leverage their size to further cement their dominance.

Lawmakers are also scrutinizing how the companies avoid taxes, are used to spread disinformation and handle people's personal information.

Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google have said in the past that they face ample competition and do not engage in anticompetitive practices. When asked Friday about the letter sent to the more than 80 companies, none of the companies offered additional comment.

The Wall Street Journal reported earlier that House lawmakers had sent requests to some of the tech companies' rivals.

The various investigations are just beginning in earnest. How far they will go, what they will uncover and whether any allegations will stand up in court are all uncertain.

It is also not clear how the tech companies will defend themselves. On Thursday, Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook's chief executive, met with President Donald Trump and held discussions on Capitol Hill about election security, privacy and other issues.

Sen. Josh Hawley, R-Mo., said Thursday that it was time for the companies to be more upfront with the public.

"We've had a lot of talk from Facebook, and we have a troubling pattern, when they're up on the Hill, of them saying things that turn out to be either very misleading or at the end of the day it's just not true or they just don't follow through on it," Hawley said.

The Department of Justice sent Google a formal request for information earlier this year, and Face-book has acknowledged it is the subject of an antitrust investigation by the Federal Trade Commission. When the agencies divided up responsibility for handling competition questions about Silicon Valley earlier this year, the Justice Department also took Apple and the FTC got Amazon.

State attorneys general around the country have also banded together to start separate investigations into Google and Facebook.

The House Judiciary committee has held multiple public hearings on the subject of the tech companies' market power as part of its inquiry. It escalated last week when it sent the formal requests to the tech companies and their critics.

In a statement last week, Rep. David Cicilline, D-R.I., chairman of the subcommittee on antitrust, which is leading the Judiciary Committee's investigation, called the document requests "an important milestone" in the fact-gathering stage.

Separately on Friday, Rep. Jerrold Nadler, D-N.Y., and Cicilline met with Zuckerberg, who left the meeting without offering a comment.

Cicilline said afterward that Zuckerberg had offered an "ongoing commitment to cooperate in the investigation, and that's a whole range of things, obviously document requests, requests for information, participation in a number of different ways."

"And I take him at his word," he said.
